items.title: Djinguereber Mosque
items.description: Built in 1327 from mud and wood, this mosque is one of the oldest in West Africa and a masterpiece of Sudano-Sahelian architecture.

items.title: Sankoré University
items.description: A center of Islamic scholarship in the 14th century, Sankoré was home to thousands of students and a vast library of ancient manuscripts.

items.title: Ahmed Baba Institute
items.description: Named after a famous scholar, this institute preserves thousands of priceless manuscripts on science, law, and philosophy.

items.title: Timbuktu Manuscripts Museum
items.description: A museum dedicated to the conservation and exhibition of Timbuktu’s ancient written heritage, dating back centuries.

items.title: Tomb of Askia Mohamed
items.description: A UNESCO World Heritage Site built in 1495, this pyramid-shaped tomb honors the powerful ruler of the Songhai Empire.

items.title: Timbuktu Desert Gate
items.address: Entrance to Timbuktu via Sahara Trail
items.description: A symbolic gateway where camel caravans once arrived, marking Timbuktu as a hub in the trans-Saharan trade routes.

items.title: Explorer’s Monument
items.description: A monument dedicated to explorers like René Caillié who braved the desert to reach Timbuktu in the 19th century.

items.title: House of Heinrich Barth
items.description: The residence of the German explorer who documented West African culture and geography during his travels in the 1850s.
